Implementation.
For the three image datasets (including MNIST, CIFAR-10, and SVHN), we simulate the federated learning setup (1 server and Kğ¾K devices) on a commodity machine with 1 IntelÂ® E5-2650 v4 CPU and 1 NVIDIAÂ® 2080Ti GPU.
We use the same local model for all the baselines and FedSiam on each dataset. For the MNIST dataset, we adopt a CNNÂ (LeCun
etÂ al., 1998) with two 5x5 convolution layers and two linear layers (21840 total parameters). For the CIFAR-10 &\& SVHN datasets, we apply a CNN with six convolution layers and three linear layers (5,852,170 total parameters). The details of each model architecture are shown in TableÂ 1.

For all the baselines and FedSiam, we adopt the weak data argumentation technique for the three datasets, and the main process contains random reflect, flip, contrast adjustment, grayscale, and crop.

references: In this section, we evaluate the performance of the proposed FedSiam framework using four settings, including one IID and three Non-IID settings. The performance of different approaches on three datasets can be found in TableÂ 5. We can observe that the proposed FedSiam achieves the best performance compared with baselines.

From TableÂ 5, we can observe that our proposed approaches still outperform all the baselines. Compared with the results of the IID setting, we find that all the accuracy drops for both Non-IID-I and Non-IID-II settings. This observation is in accord with the fact, that is, the Non-IID setting is more challenging than the IID setting for federated learning. The accuracy of most approaches in the Non-IID-II setting is larger than that in the Non-IID-I setting. In particular, the difference of the best performance in two settings on the CIFAR-10 dataset (48.11% and 58.77%) is as large as 10%. These results validate that even increasing the categories of unlabeled data may be helpful for federated semi-supervised learning.

Loss Function. To choose the suitable loss function as the consistency loss Jğ½J under the FedSSL scenario, we conduct the ablation experiments on two different losses, i.e., Mean Squared Error (MSE) loss and Kullback-Leibler (KL) Divergence loss in three datasets. From TableÂ 8, we can observe that under the IID setting, the models with MSE loss and KL Divergence loss perform better than baselines listed in TableÂ 5, and using MSE loss leads to the best accuracy on the three datasets. Thus, we choose to use the MSE loss for the IID setting. However, in the Non-IID-I setting, using KL Divergence loss can achieve much higher accuracy compared with the MSE loss on the CIFAR dataset, and on the MNIST and SVHN datasets, the modes with MSE loss still outperform the ones with KL Divergence loss. Based on these observations, we choose the KL Divergence loss for the CIFAR dataset and the MSE loss for both MNIST and SVHN datasets when running experiments under the Non-IID settings.

references: In this section, we evaluate the performance of the proposed FedSiam framework in the labels-at-server scenario, including both the IID and Non-IID settings. Since the scenario only contains unlabeled data on each client, FedAvg, FedAvg++, FedSem, and FedSiam-D do not fit this setting. Thus, we use the remaining four approaches to validate the performance, which can be found in TableÂ 6. We can observe that the proposed FedSiam achieves the best performance compared with baselines.

From TableÂ 6, we can observe that our FedSiam outperforms other baselines in labels-at-server scenario. On all three datasets, FedSiam-Î Î \Pi and FedSiam-MT achieve up to 4% performance gain compared with other baselines. The advantage of our framework is more obvious when Î³ğ›¾\gamma = 0.01. This demonstrates that FedSiam have greater performance gain in the Non-IID setting when the labeled data are extremely limited. For the SVHN dataset, FedSiam-MT model perform better than FedSiam-Î Î \Pi. We can conclude that the siamese network has more advantages for dealing with classical semi-supervised learning datasets.

references: Siamese Network & Momentum Update. We firstly experiment with the siamese network and momentum update, which controls the training of models. We report the performance of FedSiam-Nâ€‹oâ€‹Sâ€‹iâ€‹aâ€‹mğ‘ğ‘œğ‘†ğ‘–ğ‘ğ‘šNoSiam, i.e, without using the siamese network, as shown in the second row of TableÂ 8. The result suggests that the siamese network plays a important role with regard to model performance. An essential hyperparameter of FedSiam is the EMA decay on training Î±ksuperscriptğ›¼ğ‘˜\alpha^{k}. We conduct experiments to select the best value of Î±ksuperscriptğ›¼ğ‘˜\alpha^{k} and validate the sensitivity of our model to these values. From the third row of TableÂ 8, we can see that the model accuracy first increases and then degrades quickly as the Î±ksuperscriptğ›¼ğ‘˜\alpha^{k} grows. According to these results, we use Î±k=0.999superscriptğ›¼ğ‘˜0.999\alpha^{k}=0.999 in each training run, which receives the best performance among all the settings.

Quantile Curve for Ï„ğœ\tau. We experiment with the ramp-up curve for Ï„ğœ\tau, which controls the amount of unloaded parameters. We report the accuracy value of two quantile curves in the last row of TableÂ 8, with total 50 rounds training with the IID case in the label-at-client scenario. The result demonstrates that FedSiam-D achieves the best performance with the linear quantile curve on the MNIST and SVHN datasets, while the model with rectangle curve performs the best among the CIFAR-10 dataset, but the gap is small compared with the linear version. With these results, we use the linear quantile curve for the MNIST and SVHN datasets and rectangle curve for the CIFAR-10 dataset.

Loss Function. To choose the suitable loss function as the consistency loss Jğ½J under the FedSSL scenario, we conduct the ablation experiments on two different losses, i.e., Mean Squared Error (MSE) loss and Kullback-Leibler (KL) Divergence loss in three datasets. From TableÂ 8, we can observe that under the IID setting, the models with MSE loss and KL Divergence loss perform better than baselines listed in TableÂ 5, and using MSE loss leads to the best accuracy on the three datasets. Thus, we choose to use the MSE loss for the IID setting. However, in the Non-IID-I setting, using KL Divergence loss can achieve much higher accuracy compared with the MSE loss on the CIFAR dataset, and on the MNIST and SVHN datasets, the modes with MSE loss still outperform the ones with KL Divergence loss. Based on these observations, we choose the KL Divergence loss for the CIFAR dataset and the MSE loss for both MNIST and SVHN datasets when running experiments under the Non-IID settings.
